newsitem.title: UK: UK's Portillo rules out future leadership bid.
newsitem.headline: UK's Portillo rules out future leadership bid.

text.p: Michael Portillo, a former Conservative defence decretary once tipped as a future leader of his party, says he has ruled out ever running for the post.
Portillo, 44, who was the darling of the right-wing on the Conservative Party, unexpectedly lost his seat in the May 1 general election which swept Labour to power for the first time in 17 years.
He was thus ruled out of the post-election leadership campaign which saw William Hague replace John Major at the head of the party.
But in an interview with The Guardian newspaper on Saturday he said he now saw his future outside politics.
"I regard the leadership as closed forever. I got quite close to it. But the moment has passed," said Portillo, who was one of the Conservative Party's leading "Eurosceptics".
He said he was not even thinking of standing for parliament until the next election, not due for five years time.
Portillo said he was instead attracted to the "showmanship" of a television career for the next four or five years. Last month he presented a BBC television documentary about a country house.
"There's no point going back," he said. "No point speculating on what might have been because it didn't happen. It's all history."
